topics.title: The Role of Statistics in Engineering
topics.description: Introduction to statistical methods and their applications in engineering problem solving
topics.rationale: Foundational chapter establishing the context and importance of statistics in engineering

subTopics.title: Statistics Overview
subTopics.description: Understanding the role and application of statistics in engineering
subTopics.rationale: Provides context for the entire course

microTopics.title: Definition and Scope of Statistics
microTopics.description: Understanding what statistics is and how it applies to engineering
microTopics.rationale: Core concept for understanding the discipline

topics.title: Probability
topics.description: Fundamental probability concepts including independence, addition rule, intersection, union, complement, and Bayes' Theorem
topics.rationale: Essential foundation for understanding statistical inference and hypothesis testing

subTopics.title: Probability Fundamentals
subTopics.description: Basic probability concepts and rules

microTopics.title: Independence
microTopics.description: Understanding independent events and their properties

microTopics.title: Addition Rule
microTopics.description: Calculating probability of union of events

microTopics.title: Intersection
microTopics.description: Probability of multiple events occurring together

microTopics.title: Union
microTopics.description: Probability of at least one event occurring

microTopics.title: Complement
microTopics.description: Probability of an event not occurring
microTopics.rationale: Useful simplification technique for probability problems

subTopics.title: Conditional Probability and Bayes' Theorem
subTopics.description: Conditional probability and application of Bayes' Theorem
subTopics.rationale: Critical for solving complex probability problems

microTopics.title: Conditional Probability
microTopics.description: Probability of an event given another event has occurred
microTopics.rationale: Foundation for Bayes' Theorem and advanced probability

microTopics.title: Bayes' Theorem
microTopics.description: Using Bayes' Theorem to solve conditional probability problems
microTopics.rationale: Essential learning outcome for the course

topic-multiple-linear-regression.summary: Advanced calculator with unlimited predictors, automatic variable selection, residual normality checks, multicollinearity detection, and homoscedasticity testing with interpretation.

questions.prompt: A fair die is rolled. What is the probability of getting a number less than 4 OR an even number?
questions.explanation: Numbers less than 4: {1, 2, 3}. Even numbers: {2, 4, 6}. Using the addition rule: P(A  B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A  B) = 3/6 + 3/6 - 1/6 = 5/6. Wait, let me recalculate: {1, 2, 3, 4, 6} = 5 outcomes out of 6, but we need to check: less than 4 OR even = {1, 2, 3, 4, 6} = 5 outcomes, so 5/6. Actually, the union is {1, 2, 3, 4, 6} which is 4 outcomes: {1, 2, 3}  {2, 4, 6} = {1, 2, 3, 4, 6}. That's 4 outcomes, giving 4/6 = 2/3.

questions.prompt: If P(A) = 0.4 and P(B) = 0.5, and events A and B are independent, what is P(A  B)?
questions.explanation: For independent events, P(A  B) = P(A)  P(B) = 0.4  0.5 = 0.2. Independence means that the occurrence of one event does not affect the probability of the other.

questions.prompt: A bag contains 5 red balls and 3 blue balls. If one ball is drawn and found to be red, what is the probability that the next ball drawn (without replacement) is also red?
questions.explanation: This is a conditional probability problem. After drawing one red ball, there are 4 red balls and 3 blue balls remaining (7 total). The probability of drawing another red ball is 4/7. This uses the concept of conditional probability where P(second red | first red) = 4/7.

questions.prompt: A medical test has a 95% sensitivity (correctly identifies disease when present) and 90% specificity (correctly identifies no disease when absent). If a disease has a prevalence of 2% in the population, what is the probability that a person who tests positive actually has the disease? Use Bayes' Theorem.
questions.explanation: Using Bayes' Theorem: P(Disease|Positive) = P(Positive|Disease)  P(Disease) / P(Positive). P(Positive) = P(Positive|Disease)  P(Disease) + P(Positive|No Disease)  P(No Disease) = 0.95  0.02 + 0.10  0.98 = 0.019 + 0.098 = 0.117. Therefore, P(Disease|Positive) = (0.95  0.02) / 0.117 = 0.019 / 0.117  0.162  0.161.

questions.prompt: If the complement of event A has probability 0.3, what is P(A)?
questions.explanation: The complement rule states that P(A) + P(A') = 1, where A' is the complement of A. If P(A') = 0.3, then P(A) = 1 - 0.3 = 0.7. The complement represents all outcomes where event A does not occur.

questions.prompt: In a simple linear regression model, what does the term '' (epsilon) represent?

choices.label: The slope of the regression line
The random error or residual term
The correlation coefficient
The predicted value of Y

questions.explanation: In the simple linear regression model Y =  + X + , epsilon () represents the random error term or residual, which captures the deviation of observed values from the predicted regression line.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is the primary objective of the least squares method in regression analysis?

choices.label: To maximize the correlation coefficient
To minimize the sum of squared residuals
To eliminate all measurement error
To ensure the regression line passes through the origin

questions.explanation: The least squares method minimizes the sum of squared residuals ((y - )), which provides the best-fitting regression line by finding coefficients that reduce prediction errors.

questions.prompt: What does a correlation coefficient of r = -0.95 indicate about the relationship between two variables?

choices.label: A weak positive linear relationship
A strong negative linear relationship
No relationship between the variables
A perfect positive correlation

questions.explanation: A correlation coefficient of -0.95 indicates a strong negative linear relationship. The value is close to -1, showing that as one variable increases, the other tends to decrease in a nearly linear fashion.

questions.prompt: In the least squares estimation, the regression coefficient  (slope) is calculated using which formula?

choices.label: = r  (s / s)
Both A and C are correct

questions.explanation: Both formulas are equivalent ways to calculate the slope. Formula A is the direct least squares formula, and Formula C uses the correlation coefficient multiplied by the ratio of standard deviations, which yields the same result.

questions.prompt: If the simple linear regression model is  = 5 + 2X, what is the predicted value of Y when X = 3?
questions.explanation: Using the regression equation  = 5 + 2X, when X = 3:  = 5 + 2(3) = 5 + 6 = 11. This demonstrates the application of the simple linear regression model for prediction.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is a key defining characteristic of a continuous random variable?

choices.label: It can only take on a finite number of distinct values
It can take on any value within a given interval or range
Its probability at any single point is always equal to 1
It must follow a normal distribution

questions.explanation: A continuous random variable is defined as a variable that can take on any value within a specified interval or range. Unlike discrete random variables which take on distinct, countable values, continuous random variables can assume infinitely many values within their domain.

questions.prompt: For a continuous random variable X with probability density function f(x), what does the integral f(x)dx over the entire domain equal?

choices.label: Infinity

questions.explanation: The integral of a probability density function over its entire domain must equal 1. This is a fundamental property of probability density functions, ensuring that the total probability across all possible values is 1.

questions.prompt: If X follows a continuous uniform distribution on the interval [2, 8], what is the expected value of X?
questions.explanation: For a continuous uniform distribution on [a, b], the expected value is (a + b)/2. In this case, E(X) = (2 + 8)/2 = 10/2 = 5. The expected value of a uniform distribution is simply the midpoint of the interval.

questions.prompt: A standard normal distribution has a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1. What is the Z-score for a value that is 2 standard deviations above the mean?
questions.explanation: The Z-score represents the number of standard deviations a value is from the mean. If a value is 2 standard deviations above the mean, its Z-score is (value - mean)/standard deviation = 2/1 = 2.

questions.prompt: The cumulative distribution function (CDF) F(x) for a continuous random variable represents what probability?

choices.label: P(X = x)
P(X > x)
P(X  x)
P(X  x)

questions.explanation: The cumulative distribution function F(x) = P(X  x) represents the probability that the random variable X takes on a value less than or equal to x. It is the integral of the probability density function from negative infinity to x.

topics.title: Meteorological and Climatological Data Analysis
topics.description: Introduction to basic meteorological and climatological data collection, interpretation, and analysis techniques
topics.rationale: Core course content covering fundamental meteorological concepts and data analysis methods

subTopics.title: Data Interpretation and Communication
subTopics.description: Obtaining and interpreting qualitative or quantitative meteorological data and communicating findings
subTopics.rationale: Essential skill for scientific communication in meteorology

microTopics.description: Interpreting qualitative meteorological observations and phenomena

microTopics.rationale: Essential for presenting meteorological research and analysis

exams.title: Module Quizzes (1-8)
exams.description: Eight module quizzes worth 15 points each (120 points total), with potential bonus challenge quizzes for extra points. Quizzes are untimed and can be returned to at any time, but only one submission is allowed per quiz.
exams.uncertainty: Exact dates for individual module quizzes not specified; suggested schedule is one module per week, but all must be completed by October 10, 2025

questions.prompt: A meteorologist observes that cloud cover has increased from 20% to 80% over the past 6 hours, and surface temperature has dropped by 5C. Which hypothesis would be most appropriate to test based on these observations?

choices.label: Increased cloud cover causes temperature increases in all weather systems
Increased cloud cover is associated with reduced solar radiation reaching the surface, leading to temperature decreases
Temperature changes are independent of cloud cover variations
Cloud cover and temperature are unrelated phenomena in atmospheric dynamics

questions.explanation: The correct hypothesis logically connects the observed phenomena (increased cloud cover and temperature decrease) through a known physical mechanism (reduced solar radiation). This represents sound hypothesis construction based on qualitative observations and understanding of atmospheric processes.

questions.prompt: A climate researcher collected precipitation data from 50 weather stations over 30 years. The dataset shows a mean annual precipitation of 850 mm with a standard deviation of 120 mm. Which statement best describes the appropriate use of this quantitative data?

choices.label: The data can only be used qualitatively to describe general weather patterns
The data should be used to calculate statistical measures and identify trends in precipitation patterns across the region
The data is too large to analyze and should be reduced to a single station
Quantitative precipitation data cannot be used to make predictions about future climate

questions.explanation: Quantitative meteorological data like precipitation measurements are specifically designed to be analyzed statistically to identify patterns, trends, and variations. The mean and standard deviation provided are appropriate statistical measures for this type of numerical dataset.

questions.prompt: A scientist claims that 'global temperatures have increased by 1.1C over the past century due to increased atmospheric CO2.' To properly assess the validity of this claim, which approach would be most rigorous?

choices.label: Accept the claim without verification since it comes from a scientist
Examine the quality of temperature records, evaluate the strength of evidence linking CO2 to warming, and consider alternative explanations
Reject the claim because temperature varies naturally
Only consider recent data from the past 10 years to verify the claim

questions.explanation: Claim validity assessment requires critical evaluation of evidence quality, consideration of causal mechanisms, and examination of alternative explanations. This approach integrates evidence evaluation and critical thinking rather than accepting claims uncritically or dismissing them outright.

questions.prompt: When presenting findings about a severe drought to policymakers, a meteorologist should integrate both qualitative observations (e.g., 'farmers reported crop failures') and quantitative data (e.g., 'precipitation was 40% below the 30-year average'). Why is this integration important?

choices.label: Qualitative data is always more convincing than quantitative data
Quantitative data alone provides complete understanding without needing observations
Combining both types of evidence creates a more compelling and comprehensive argument that addresses both the magnitude and real-world impact of the phenomenon
Integration of different data types reduces the scientific credibility of findings

questions.explanation: Effective scientific communication and argument construction requires evidence integrationcombining qualitative and quantitative evidence strengthens arguments by providing both numerical rigor and contextual understanding. This approach demonstrates how meteorological findings connect to real-world impacts.

questions.prompt: A meteorologist develops a model showing how warm ocean temperatures lead to increased atmospheric moisture, which then produces more intense hurricanes. This model is used to explain why Category 5 hurricanes have become more frequent in recent decades. Which aspect of scientific modeling is being demonstrated here?

choices.label: The model is purely theoretical and has no connection to real phenomena
The model explains observable weather phenomena by showing the physical processes and causal relationships involved
Models cannot be used to explain why weather patterns change over time
The model proves that ocean temperature is the only factor affecting hurricane intensity

questions.explanation: This demonstrates phenomenon explanation through model developmentthe model connects physical processes (ocean warming  moisture increase  hurricane intensification) to explain observable changes in hurricane frequency. Models serve to illustrate the mechanisms underlying meteorological phenomena.

topic-statistics-role.title: Applied Statistics and Probability for Engineers - Chapter 1
topic-statistics-role.summary: Required textbook Chapter 1 covering the role of statistics in engineering

topic-probability.title: Applied Statistics and Probability for Engineers - Chapter 2
topic-probability.summary: Required textbook Chapter 2 covering probability theory, Bayes' Theorem, and conditional probability

exams.title: Exam 1
exams.description: First midterm exam covering Chapters 1-6: The Role of Statistics in Engineering, Probability (independence, addition rule, intersection, union, complement, Bayes' Theorem), Discrete Random Variables (Discrete Uniform, Poisson, Bernoulli, Binomial, expected value, variance, pmf, CDF), Continuous Random Variables (Continuous Uniform, Normal, Standard Normal, Exponential, expected value, variance, pdf, CDF), and Descriptive Statistics (histograms, Pareto charts). 10% of exam covers information only given in class.

exams.title: Exam 2
exams.description: Second midterm exam covering Chapters 7-10: Point Estimation and Sampling Distributions (sample mean, sample variance, Central Limit Theorem), Statistical Intervals for a Single Sample (mean, variance, proportion), Tests of Hypothesis for a Single Sample (mean, variance, proportion), and Statistical Inference for Two Samples (confidence intervals and hypothesis tests for difference between means, equality of variances, paired T-test, difference between proportions). 10% of exam covers information only given in class.

exams.title: Exam 3
exams.description: Third midterm exam covering Chapters 11-12 and 15: Simple Linear Regression and Correlation, Multiple Linear Regression, and Statistical Process Control (X-bar and R charts). 10% of exam covers information only given in class. Lowest of three midterm scores is dropped.

exams.title: Final Exam
exams.description: Cumulative final exam covering all course material from Chapters 1-15. Comprehensive assessment of all learning outcomes. Held at a different time than regular class meetings.

questions.prompt: In engineering applications, what is the primary role of statistics?

choices.label: To provide exact predictions without any uncertainty
To analyze data, identify patterns, and make informed decisions under uncertainty
To replace the need for engineering experiments and testing
To eliminate all sources of variability in manufacturing processes

questions.explanation: Statistics is fundamentally about analyzing data, identifying patterns, and making informed decisions in the presence of uncertainty. It does not provide exact predictions, cannot replace experiments, and acknowledges that variability exists in real-world systems. In engineering, statistics helps us understand and manage this uncertainty.

questions.prompt: Two events A and B are considered independent if:

choices.label: They cannot occur at the same time
The occurrence of one event does not affect the probability of the other event occurring
They always occur together
The sum of their probabilities equals 1

questions.explanation: Two events are independent if the occurrence of one event does not change the probability of the other event occurring. Mathematically, this means P(AB) = P(A)P(B). This is the defining characteristic of independence in probability theory.

questions.prompt: A quality control engineer needs to find the probability that a component is defective given that it failed a test. Which probability concept is most appropriate to use?

choices.label: Union of events
Complement rule
Bayes' Theorem
Addition rule

questions.explanation: Bayes' Theorem is specifically designed to find the probability of an event (component is defective) given that another event has occurred (component failed a test). This is a classic application of conditional probability using Bayes' Theorem, which allows us to update probabilities based on new evidence or test results.

questions.prompt: Which of the following best describes the primary role of statistics in engineering?

choices.label: To provide exact predictions without any uncertainty or variability
To collect, analyze, and interpret data to support decision-making and problem-solving
To replace experimental testing with purely theoretical calculations
To eliminate all sources of error in engineering measurements

questions.explanation: Statistics is fundamentally about collecting, analyzing, and interpreting data to make informed decisions. In engineering, it helps manage uncertainty, variability, and complexity in real-world problems. It does not provide exact predictions without uncertainty, nor does it replace experimentation or eliminate all errors.

questions.prompt: Why is understanding statistics considered essential for modern engineers?

choices.label: Because it is required by all international engineering certifications
Because engineers must interpret experimental data, assess quality, manage risks, and optimize processes in the presence of variability
Because it eliminates the need for physical prototyping and testing
Because statistical knowledge is only relevant for researchers, not practicing engineers

questions.explanation: Statistics is essential for engineers because real-world systems contain variability and uncertainty. Engineers use statistics to interpret experimental results, ensure product quality, assess and manage risks, and optimize designs and processes. It complements rather than replaces physical testing and is vital for all practicing engineers.

questions.prompt: In an engineering context, which scenario best demonstrates the application of statistics?

choices.label: Using a single measurement from one test to determine if a design meets specifications
Collecting multiple measurements from repeated tests, analyzing variability, and using probability to assess whether the design meets specifications
Relying solely on theoretical calculations without any empirical data
Making engineering decisions based purely on intuition and past experience

questions.explanation: Statistics is properly applied when engineers collect multiple data points, account for variability, and use statistical methods to make evidence-based conclusions. A single measurement is insufficient due to natural variability. Theoretical calculations alone and intuition-based decisions do not leverage the power of statistical analysis to handle real-world uncertainty.
